channel.title: Using Scala as a scripting language

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Death Style, post:28, topic:554726”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=673647.msg4504776#msg4504776 date=1456102375]
There are so many things wrong with what you posted…
[/quote]
Well I figured I would garner this kind of response so I’ll accept the criticism.

in any ordinary language it would be trivial to figure out what you were looking at but with the godawful syntax (((((((()()))(()))()()))))) and names (seriously, set!, car, cdr?)

First of all, if you need to use set! you’re most likely doing FP wrong.

The program was already using that in the state it was given to me. I do FP in javascript anyway.

I also think having to iterate a list just to reach an element in question instead of just directly accessing it is mindblowingly inefficient when you think about every list an application would use.

Scheme has vectors.

I have to ask what is the point of lists then? I’ll take the blame and say it’s my fault I wasn’t made aware of it nor the rest of my class…

but consider how horribly inefficient a list/merge sort would be. you can’t even do a binary search with that kind of limitation.

I don’t know what you mean here. In FP, the idea is not to mutate your data but instead to use that as an input to a function to compute whatever you need to do, then return its transformation. You never modify data in-place (ie. set!), it’s just not the functional way. Binary searches are very possible here.

Well I use .map in js so I’m aware of the idea behind it. Just with my understanding that a list was the only native collection type doing such tasks would be awful. I’m not even sure how you would do a binary search with a list since it can only be traversed in one direction; you would use a vector. And even if it’s against the “FP” practice of modifying data I would rather modify a 1 million collection to be in the correct order than load into memory another 1 million collection that is the sorted version.

To be honest, alot of these problems stem from not fully understanding the functional paradigm and Scheme. Not trying to be a dick; just my two cents.

I do FP in JS and most of my problems are with the syntax, choice of names for basic operations, and my belief that a one-direction list was the only way to store things. No excuse for my ignorance though so I’ll accept that.

I mean, I probably just had a shitty class on it. Vectors seem like a pretty significant thing and that was never brought up in class. Not trying to toot my horn or anything but I was rank 1 in my uni class that went over scheme so I figured if I was having problems after landing perfect scores on the tests and homework there wasn’t much to excuse the shortcomings I had with it.

if the bane of lisp programming was dealing with parentheses for you then you probably just had a shitty text editor that couldn’t deal with them (hint: that also includes vim). scheme’s (and racket’s) functions are actually named fairly reasonably. if you take a look at common lisp, THEN you should have a fun time.

I used Dr. Racket and I really spent more time trying to count parenthesis than necessary. I’m not saying a language is bad because the syntax is awful but I can only imagine how much developer time is wasted trying to balance parenthesis when something like a space could have sufficed. I still don’t think car or cdr is an appropriate name and my professor even told me it was a mistake but I’ll take that with a grain of salt I guess.

although i actually agree with you on that it’s more difficult to produce larger programs, especially if you don’t think through the design well in the beginning. to me at least, lisp is just as big of a write-only language as C is – i can only read my own code, and not anybody else’s. it’s not the parens per se that make this problematic for me (or anybody, really), but rather the general lisp programming style: s-exps in a fp paradigm that, combined, make this hard for me. i know many seasoned lisp coders don’t have a problem with it anymore though; perhaps it just takes a lot of time. sometimes you have to read inside-out (i.e. start reading the deepest nested expressions first). i don’t see how implementing a sort or binary search would be a problem though. keep in mind if you aren’t thinking recursively you will have a worse time.

I mean I can think recursively. That was the only way to get through that class. I guess looking at C-syntax code is so much more intuitive to me.

I’m sure there’s probably more at fault with me if so many people are successful with it but tbh just looking back at my lab I struggle to see how people can get into the groove of making large code bases. I spent more time just trying to understand what was happening than actually doing anything. Here’s a lab sample I had to do in that class:

But that could just be me and maybe that’s intuitive to you guys. Anyway thanks for the feedback.[/quote]

http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61a/su10/resources/sp11-Jordy/vector-vs-list.html

but yeah, sometimes writing imperative code will be far more practical. that’s why most lisps are multi-paradigmal, so you can do what you actually need to do. in reality you can’t be completely pure without sacrificing something, especially when you are dealing with states that are constantly changing (like i/o). i mean haskell has a bunch of solutions to that, but meh, it’s fuken haskell. fp is just an ideal; if something can be done well without modifying state, then nice.

most editors in general are not suitable for editing lisp code. coloring parens and correct spacing make things much more readable.

car and cdr are historical names, and brevity was important back then.

fp emphasizes functions, where each function should be relatively small with one specific purpose. of course this can’t always be done perfectly but in general if you split up your functions things will be easier to comprehend.

Read full topic
item.source: Using Scala as a scripting language

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

justaguy:

There are so many things wrong with what you posted…

Well I figured I would garner this kind of response so I’ll accept the criticism.

[quote author=Death Style link=topic=673647.msg4504771#msg4504771 date=1456099217] in any ordinary language it would be trivial to figure out what you were looking at but with the godawful syntax (((((((()()))(()))()()))))) and names (seriously, set!, car, cdr?) [/quote] First of all, if you need to use set! you're most likely doing FP wrong.
The program was already using that in the state it was given to me. I do FP in javascript anyway.
[quote author=Death Style link=topic=673647.msg4504771#msg4504771 date=1456099217] I also think having to iterate a list just to reach an element in question instead of just directly accessing it is mindblowingly inefficient when you think about every list an application would use. [/quote] Scheme has vectors.
I have to ask what is the point of lists then? I'll take the blame and say it's my fault I wasn't made aware of it nor the rest of my class...
[quote author=Death Style link=topic=673647.msg4504771#msg4504771 date=1456099217] but consider how horribly inefficient a list/merge sort would be. you can't even do a binary search with that kind of limitation. [/quote] I don't know what you mean here. In FP, the idea is not to mutate your data but instead to use that as an input to a function to compute whatever you need to do, then return its transformation. You never modify data in-place (ie. set!), it's just not the functional way. Binary searches are very possible here.
Well I use .map in js so I'm aware of the idea behind it. Just with my understanding that a list was the only native collection type doing such tasks would be awful. I'm not even sure how you would do a binary search with a list since it can only be traversed in one direction; you would use a vector. And even if it's against the "FP" practice of modifying data I would rather modify a 1 million collection to be in the correct order than load into memory another 1 million collection that is the sorted version.
To be honest, alot of these problems stem from not fully understanding the functional paradigm and Scheme. Not trying to be a dick; just my two cents.
I do FP in JS and most of my problems are with the syntax, choice of names for basic operations, and my belief that a one-direction list was the only way to store things. No excuse for my ignorance though so I'll accept that.

I mean, I probably just had a shitty class on it. Vectors seem like a pretty significant thing and that was never brought up in class. Not trying to toot my horn or anything but I was rank 1 in my uni class that went over scheme so I figured if I was having problems after landing perfect scores on the tests and homework there wasn’t much to excuse the shortcomings I had with it.

Whackatre:

if the bane of lisp programming was dealing with parentheses for you then you probably just had a shitty text editor that couldn’t deal with them (hint: that also includes vim). scheme’s (and racket’s) functions are actually named fairly reasonably. if you take a look at common lisp, THEN you should have a fun time.

I used Dr. Racket and I really spent more time trying to count parenthesis than necessary. I’m not saying a language is bad because the syntax is awful but I can only imagine how much developer time is wasted trying to balance parenthesis when something like a space could have sufficed. I still don’t think car or cdr is an appropriate name and my professor even told me it was a mistake but I’ll take that with a grain of salt I guess.

although i actually agree with you on that it's more difficult to produce larger programs, especially if you don't think through the design well in the beginning. to me at least, lisp is just as big of a write-only language as C is -- i can only read my own code, and not anybody else's. it's not the parens per se that make this problematic for me (or anybody, really), but rather the general lisp programming style: s-exps in a fp paradigm that, combined, make this hard for me. i know many seasoned lisp coders don't have a problem with it anymore though; perhaps it just takes a lot of time. :) sometimes you have to read inside-out (i.e. start reading the deepest nested expressions first). i don't see how implementing a sort or binary search would be a problem though. keep in mind if you aren't thinking recursively you *will* have a worse time.
I mean I can think recursively. That was the only way to get through that class. I guess looking at C-syntax code is so much more intuitive to me.

I’m sure there’s probably more at fault with me if so many people are successful with it but tbh just looking back at my lab I struggle to see how people can get into the groove of making large code bases. I spent more time just trying to understand what was happening than actually doing anything. Here’s a lab sample I had to do in that class:

But that could just be me and maybe that’s intuitive to you guys. Anyway thanks for the feedback.

item.source: Using Scala as a scripting language

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Death Style, post:25, topic:554726”]I had an assignment to fix my professor’s broken math expression calculator that involved recursively digging into user-input parenthetical statements and holding values on recursive function calls down the stack and back up. in any ordinary language it would be trivial to figure out what you were looking at but with the godawful syntax (((((((()()))(()))()()))))) and names (seriously, set!, car, cdr?) I spent way too many hours just trying to figure out what abomination I was even looking at before I even began coding the solution.

it’s not bad for small functions but trying to make something actually productive and readable in that language is a fallacy to me. you have to use a new set of parenthesis just to declare variables and the deeper you go the harder it becomes for another person to even grasp what is happening. I also think having to iterate a list just to reach an element in question instead of just directly accessing it is mindblowingly inefficient when you think about every list an application would use. granted you probably shouldn’t be using a list if you need to directly access certain members, but consider how horribly inefficient a list/merge sort would be. you can’t even do a binary search with that kind of limitation. I’m sure the code looks pretty but that doesn’t mean much when it’s marginally slower. maybe it’s just my imagination and the implementation isn’t so bad, but it’s definitely not something I’d want to do in scheme.

I’m probably biased since the day I first read a line of clojurescript but w.e[/quote]

if the bane of lisp programming was dealing with parentheses for you then you probably just had a shitty text editor that couldn’t deal with them (hint: that also includes vim). scheme’s (and racket’s) functions are actually named fairly reasonably. if you take a look at common lisp, THEN you should have a fun time.

although i actually agree with you on that it’s more difficult to produce larger programs, especially if you don’t think through the design well in the beginning. to me at least, lisp is just as big of a write-only language as C is – i can only read my own code, and not anybody else’s. it’s not the parens per se that make this problematic for me (or anybody, really), but rather the general lisp programming style: s-exps in a fp paradigm that, combined, make this hard for me. i know many seasoned lisp coders don’t have a problem with it anymore though; perhaps it just takes a lot of time. sometimes you have to read inside-out (i.e. start reading the deepest nested expressions first). i don’t see how implementing a sort or binary search would be a problem though. keep in mind if you aren’t thinking recursively you will have a worse time.

Read full topic

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

There are so many things wrong with what you posted…

Death Style:

in any ordinary language it would be trivial to figure out what you were looking at but with the godawful syntax (((((((()()))(()))()()))))) and names (seriously, set!, car, cdr?)

First of all, if you need to use set! you’re most likely doing FP wrong.

Death Style:

I also think having to iterate a list just to reach an element in question instead of just directly accessing it is mindblowingly inefficient when you think about every list an application would use.

Scheme has vectors.

Death Style:

but consider how horribly inefficient a list/merge sort would be. you can’t even do a binary search with that kind of limitation.

I don’t know what you mean here. In FP, the idea is not to mutate your data but instead to use that as an input to a function to compute whatever you need to do, then return its transformation. You never modify data in-place (ie. set!), it’s just not the functional way. Binary searches are very possible here.

To be honest, alot of these problems stem from not fully understanding the functional paradigm and Scheme. Not trying to be a dick; just my two cents.

Read full topic
item.source: Using Scala as a scripting language

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

I had an assignment to fix my professor’s broken math expression calculator that involved recursively digging into user-input parenthetical statements and holding values on recursive function calls down the stack and back up. in any ordinary language it would be trivial to figure out what you were looking at but with the godawful syntax (((((((()()))(()))()()))))) and names (seriously, set!, car, cdr?) I spent way too many hours just trying to figure out what abomination I was even looking at before I even began coding the solution.

it’s not bad for small functions but trying to make something actually productive and readable in that language is a fallacy to me. you have to use a new set of parenthesis just to declare variables and the deeper you go the harder it becomes for another person to even grasp what is happening. I also think having to iterate a list just to reach an element in question instead of just directly accessing it is mindblowingly inefficient when you think about every list an application would use. granted you probably shouldn’t be using a list if you need to directly access certain members, but consider how horribly inefficient a list/merge sort would be. you can’t even do a binary search with that kind of limitation. I’m sure the code looks pretty but that doesn’t mean much when it’s marginally slower. maybe it’s just my imagination and the implementation isn’t so bad, but it’s definitely not something I’d want to do in scheme.

I’m probably biased since the day I first read a line of clojurescript but w.e

Read full topic

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Bowser jr:

What did you do to fix it?

because the plugin system is based on event listeners, the scripts are only evaluated once on startup. so what I did was just evaluate the bootstrap (the first block of code in OP) -> script dependencies -> misc. scripts (second code block in OP would fall under this) in that order

i had to define a file that specifically declares what order the “script dependencies” should be evaluated in, to ensure that a script dependency that depends on another script dependency is evaluated after what it depends on

this also means that circular script dependencies won’t work, but there’s ways around that so I don’t think it’ll be an issue

Read full topic
item.source: Using Scala as a scripting language

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language

I don’t see your problem. You import the first file into the second, and then you can use it?
[/quote]
my problem is that i have multiple scripts just like the second, i need the first script to have “global” state

edit: i got it working, thanks anyway[/quote]
What did you do to fix it?

item.source: Using Scala as a scripting language

item.title: Using Scala as a scripting language
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Yz85Racer:

Are you using scala for a scripting language for a RuneScape server? Interesting

yeah! originally I was compiling the Scala code into bytecode and using DelayedInit to create a function that wraps around the initialization code, so all I had to do was instantiate the classes on startup and add the wrapped function to a map as a listener (with the event class type as the key)

but this proved not to be sufficient enough because it was still too verbose (a top level class was required for it to work, annoying) plus DelayedInit is deprecated and will probably be removed soon so now I’m just using Scala as a scripting language. its nice because I have a lot more control over exactly how I want it to be

[quote=“sini, post:5, topic:554726”]Why
not
nashorn[/quote]
JavaScript?
no
thank
you

Read full topic
